ratings.question_text: How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: This was an excellent course! I learned a lot from the different speakers, from engaging with the other students, from the professor, and from the field trip to DC.
Question 9: The field trip to New York was the best part of the class. I learned a lot from all our leaders we met with. I liked that the class culminated with this trip.
Overall, I would give the class portion of the course a 4, but the field trip was extremely beneficial from a career development and learning about leadership perspective.

I would like this class to have a more specific forestry focus. Professor Oliver is full of great ideas, wisdom and insight. However, I felt that many of the other students were not as interested in the class as I was. This dragged down the class on the whole. To remedy this, I think that a more specific focus (forestry) would have helped to weed out the freeriders who really hamstrung the discussions with their stone-faced (and silent) presence.

Overall, the course was disappointing and unstructured. It was unclear what themes in leadership we weresupposed to learn and most of the course for the semester was dedicated to planning a 2-day visit to Washington DC or NYC.
Prof Chad made students to feel as real leaders. I learnt a lot from his styles of dealing with various issues.
The field trip. We met so many interesting people, who were really inspiring.
Actually meeting with leaders and professionals was the highlight of the class. In addition to the DC trip, the visitors to class were great.
THe field trip and meeting with individual leaders.
The trip to DC was the best thing. It was interesting and fun.
The readings, the field trip, the speakers.
the field trip to washington DC and in class discussion, especially my classmates' thoughtful observations, comments, questions, and stories.
Professor Oliver is a constant source of valuable stories, encouragement and insight.The field trip was fantastic- a truly great opportunity.
The trip to DC was absolutely enriching.
Visiting speakers, however there were few of these outside of the field trip.
The light work load.
The field trip to DC. I really enjoyed the trip and getting to meet the people we did.
Excellent trip to DC! I learned a great deal from my classmates during classroom discussions, from the leaders we met in Washington, and from the professor.
The field trips, guest speakers and class interactions!
The excellently planed trip to DC. and class exercises

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: I think this course was run very well.

The format of the class eats up a lot of time. Though it is important to be able to run a meeting, trying to implement robert's rule of order was a waste of a lot of time. Rather, spend time in class in discussion about readings, guest speakers, upcoming speakers, and class reflections.There was also too much time spent in class planning the trips. If we had less time allotted to planning we would have gotten it done in less time. Then we could have had more time to discuss. The class really didn't feel like a seminar at all, we barely got into engaging and meaningful discussion.More follow-up on readings. Don't just give them to us, make us talk about them the next week. Bring up our class reflections during class time, question us, challenge us.The class can still be fun while being much more stimulating. Ask us to do small, simple assignments each week to keep us engaged. For example, research a current leader in your field and report back on successes/challenges.Really this can be summed up by saying that we need to be more engaged. We need to be pushed a little. We want to participate, but if the bar is set so low, we lose interest early on and resign the class to something that we don't need to put effort into.
Not enough structure to the course assignments. Reflections were suppose to be handed in for each class, but not everyone did.

I wish more time had been allotted for class discussions. The majority of class time was spent on planning the field trip and we rarely discussed the readings (which were really interesting!) I think it would have been a more enriching experience if we had been able to discuss the readings and talk about leadership instead of planning for the field trip.

I wish we'd spent more time in class discussing leadership challenges as a group, rather than listening to lectures. my classmates have so many useful stories and thoughts about leadership. Also, I think the content of the course needs to be strengthened. a stronger focus on why environmental leadership is different from traditional leadership would help. As would a more rigorous and structured set of units to be covered over the course of the semester.

Discussions- we need to have students who are interested in talking, debating, and going deeper into the material. Required readings, student-led discussions, and more consistent out of class assignments would help drive a more lively and fulfilling class.

This entire course needs to be redesigned. There were infrequent lectures and guest speakers. There was almost no discussion of assigned readings -- several students commented that they did not do the reading, given that it was never covered in class.
The professor and curriculum.

The lectures on leadership seemed archaic and not relevant to natural resource/ environmental managers. The leadership we learned was about factories and the military which is not the kind of leadership I will ever be engaged in.While we were supposed to learn about leadership through "doing" by planning the DC trip, the process was made far more complex then it should have been. We did not need to take up class time to do this. Also we were not given actual decision making authority as Chad seemed to take all the real decisions into his own hands.The pudding assignment was terrible. It didn't take any ingenuity on the part of the students. It should have been for each team to come up with a dessert and make it on their own through teamwork. If we are to be leaders we need to be able to think for ourselves.It is unfortunate that this class is an MF capstone course as I think it is an example of the worst teaching and lack of student creativity at FES.
More funding!
duration and Trip and interaction with world leaders may be increased

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: Instructor was excellent. Always had time to speak with students and very responsive to ideas and suggestions.
Professor Oliver was very helpful and I enjoyed his feedback on my reflection papers.
Chad was always willing to answer any student questions.
Chad was available and seemed open to feedback, but did not solicit it actively.
Professor Oliver was always available and very helpful. I am glad to have gotten to know him and will continue to connect with him on all things forestry-related.
There was little content in the class about which to seek help.
The professor was available to students but his answers were not always clear
Instructor was very helpful during frequent contacts
No match, it was excellent

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: This was a great course to take since I plan to work in DC upon graduation. It was very interesting to hear how successful leaders have shaped their career and how they make their decisions.
I wanted to learn more about leadership and thought this course would be a good overview.
FES is dedicated to training leaders, so this course is very relevant to the overall program.

This course is a capstone course for the MF. It is a requirement and is a culminating experience. As such, I think it should have more of a forestry focus. The majority of the class did not have an interest in forests and some even lacked an expressed interest in natural resources management. There were so many wonderful opportunities for discussion about the difficulties surrounding natural resources management- but many of these were squandered because people were pegging away on their laptops and not paying attention nor showing any interest.
It was a good introduction to leadership and career information that you do not generally learn in school.
I had several other highly work-intensive courses this semester and needed a less demanding course. In that regard, it worked out well. As far as substantive learning, it was essentially useless.
It has prepared me to excel in future leadership positions
yes this is expected from me by the State Govt. In my position I am expected to be a good leader for the team working with me.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted to learn more about leadership styles and effective management.
I also wanted to network for jobs in DC and NYC and thought this would be a good way to meet people in leadership positions.
To lean more about institutional leadership.
To learn more about leadership and learn/listen to leaders out in the field.
I knew the field trip to DC would be extremely interesting and valuable.
This was a required course. However, I would have taken it anyway in order to spend some time with Professor Oliver discussing forestry.
To prepare myself for a leadership position in civil service
The light work load.
Because it fit into my schedule and I was looking for a course that had a minimal work load.
To achieve Question 15
To upgrade my leadership qualities

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes. This was an excellent course. I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in learning about leadership styles, and learning about how others navigated their careers. Professor Oliver had some excellent speakers during the course of the semester and the final DC trip really capped it off.
Yes.
Yes.
No.
Not really. see suggested improvements above.
Yes.
yes.
No. Unfortunately, this was a disappointment.
No. I didn't expect a lot, but I got even less.
No.
Yes
Yes, it even exceeded my expectations
excellent

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes. More.
Yes.
Yes
I was expecting to get more out of this class.
I got much more than expected, especially considering that I was the one in charge of the field trip.

Not exactly- I was hoping for a smaller and more dynamic class filled with people who were interested in having discussions based around natural resources management. I think those people self-identified in the classroom, but then we had our discussion stifled by a silent and uninterested majority.The field trip, however, was an amazing experience and definitely lived up to my expectations.
And more.
No. I did not walk away better understanding major themes in 'leadership in natural resources.'
No. I got nothing. A few laughs, maybe.
No
Yes
Yes
Yes, beyond that expectation also!

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was really interesting to see how our group dynamic panned out with 14 people on the DC team. We worked well together and self organized to meet with DC leaders: from the scheduling, to the student bios, to the transportation and hotel, to the gifts. The students ran the whole event.
The groupwork component of this class was a highlight. We really learned a lot about ourselves and our abilities within a group.
It was a good exercise in planning a trip with other individuals. Frustrating at times because different people put in different amounts of work to planning the trip.
It was very good! The structure of the groups and the ability to see how leadership and organizations work on the micro and macro level was very useful.

Advantages = can delegate and distribute the work load, gain new perspectives from other team members.Disadvantages = differences in leadership and communication styles can sometimes lead to friction.
my classmates have a lot of strong skills and interesting experiences that they brought to our discussions.

The planning of the field trip was THE central activity of the class. I learned a lot about myself during the process. I also learned a lot about identifying people with whom I am not interested in working. It was not that the experience was bad, it was just that I now have a better sense for who I work well with and who I will avoid when possible.

I enjoyed getting to know my classmates through the group work. I thought what could have been relatively simple (planning the trip) was made complex by chain of command etc. It was nice that everyone seemed to pull their weight with the group work.
Advantage: Learned a lot about team work and collaboration skillsDisadvantage: vulnerability to miscommunication, etc.
Very Advantageous.

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: If you have ever wanted to take more of a leadership position but haven't had the opportunity, this is a great time to get experience managing people and a project.
You get out of it what you put into it. It can be a fulfilling course if you want it to be.

It's a minimal workload for a three credit course, and the field trip and speakers were interesting. Chad worked hard to make the experience an enjoyable one. Unfortunately the majority of class time was spent on planning the field trip as opposed to discussing the readings/talking about leadership.
If you haven't had any previous experience as a leader, take this class.Just take it. You will learn a LOT.
Press for more discussions earlier in the course. Also, there should be assigned readings with students leading discussions.
Be prepared to go with the flow and most of the learning will come from observing your colleagues.

If the course continues to be what it was this year, do not take this course if you are looking to learn anything significant beyond the opportunity to speak with some mid-level and a few high-level natural resources professionals.
Don't take this course.
Be fully engaged in all its activities for best results!
They should participate in class interactions.
